name: Chlordiazepoxide (Librium)
summary: A long-acting benzodiazepine used for anxiety disorders and alcohol withdrawal management.
description: Chlordiazepoxide, marketed as Librium, is a long-acting benzodiazepine with anxiolytic, sedative, and muscle relaxant properties. It was the first benzodiazepine introduced into clinical practice and is still used today, particularly for managing alcohol withdrawal syndrome due to its long half-life and smoother withdrawal profile. It enhances the effects of GABA at the GABA-A receptor, leading to central nervous system depression.

sections.text: Potentiates GABAergic neurotransmission by binding to the benzodiazepine site on the GABA-A receptor, increasing chloride influx and neuronal inhibition.

adult.alcohol-withdrawal: 50–100 mg initially, may repeat after 2–4 hours as needed; taper over several days
adult.preoperative-anxiety: 5–10 mg orally 3–4 times daily before surgery

sections.geriatric: Use lowest effective dose (e.g., 5 mg 2–3 times daily) to minimize sedation and falls
sections.hepatic_impairment: Use with caution; dose reduction may be required
sections.renal_impairment: Generally no adjustment, but monitor closely

sections.text: Onset within 1–3 hours orally; duration of effect 24–48 hours due to long half-life and active metabolites.

sections.black_box: Concomitant use with opioids may result in profound sedation, respiratory depression, coma, and death.
other: Risk of dependence, abuse, and withdrawal symptoms with prolonged use
Caution in patients with depression or history of substance use disorder

sections.pregnancy: Category D; avoid unless necessary due to risk of fetal harm
sections.lactation: Excreted in breast milk; may cause sedation in infant
sections.pediatrics: Safety not established; avoid unless benefits outweigh risks
sections.geriatrics: Increased risk of sedation, falls, and confusion; use lowest effective dose

sections.text: Taper gradually over weeks to prevent withdrawal symptoms such as insomnia, agitation, tremors, and seizures.

items: Preferred benzodiazepine for alcohol withdrawal due to long half-life
Less frequent dosing compared to shorter-acting benzodiazepines
Active metabolites prolong therapeutic and withdrawal effects
